translated: Fayuan zhulin, Scroll 27
Compiled by Shi Daoshi, a monk from Ximing Temple

original: 19 至誠篇(二七)至誠篇第十九此有八部
analyzed: 19 至誠篇(二七)至誠篇第十九此有八部
translated: Chapter 19: Utmost Sincerity (Part 27), in 8 sections

original: 述意部求寶部求戒部求忍部求進部求定部求果部濟難部1 述意部述意部第一夫至誠所感無神弗應。
analyzed: 述意部求寶部求戒部求忍部求進部求定部求果部濟難部1 述意部述意部第一夫至誠所感無神弗應。
translated: Section 1: Expressing the Meaning. The utmost sincerity moves the gods, and no spirit does not respond.
Great beings operate their minds, and no mechanism does not respond.
Strive to make one's intentions reach the end of the future.

original: 所以一一弘誓莫不忍智相應。
analyzed: 所以一一弘誓莫不忍智相應。
translated: Therefore, each and every great vow is not without the corresponding forbearance and wisdom.

original: 心心廣博皆在阿惟越致。
analyzed: 心心廣博皆在阿惟越致。
translated: Each and every mind is vast, all in the stage of nonretrogression.
If one does not establish practices more important than pine and bamboo,
And make vows surpassing gold and stone,
Protect and uphold with one's life, and deeply rescue and deliver.
Propagate the Way to repay the four kinds of kindness.
Nurture virtue to benefit the three existences.

original: 此則功被三祇果周十地也。
analyzed: 此則功被三祇果周十地也。
translated: This then covers the three asaṃkhyeya kalpas with merit and completes the ten grounds.

original: 2 求寶部求寶部第二大志經云。
analyzed: 2 求寶部求寶部第二大志經云。
translated: Section 2: Seeking Treasures. The Dazhi Sutra says:
In the past, there was a country called Huanle.
There was a householder named Mahādana.
His wife was named Caṇḍā.
and gave birth to a son.
His appearance was upright and rare in the world.
As soon as he was born, he spoke.
He made a vow, saying:
I will give alms and benefit the poor.
His parents named him Great Intention.

original: 至年十七為眾生故發意入海。
analyzed: 至年十七為眾生故發意入海。
translated: At the age of seventeen, for the sake of sentient beings, he set his mind on entering the ocean.
To obtain the bright moon treasure pearl and save sentient beings.
First entering the ocean, he reached the silver city.
The dragon king gave him the bright moon pearl.
There were twenty li of treasures.
Going further, he reached the golden city.
The dragon king gave him the bright moon pearl.
There were forty li of treasures.
Going further, he reached the crystal city.
The dragon king gave him the bright moon pearl.
This pearl had sixty li of treasures.
Going further, he reached the lapis lazuli city.
The dragon king gave him the bright moon pearl.
This pearl had eighty li of treasures.
Later, when I attained the Way, I wished for him to be my disciple.
With a pure mind, his offerings will surpass those of today.
May he always attain wisdom.
Daoyi accepted the pearl and left.
On his way back to his home country, he passed through the ocean.
The sea gods discussed among themselves,

original: 我海中雖多眾珍名寶無有此珠。
analyzed: 我海中雖多眾珍名寶無有此珠。
translated: Although there are many precious treasures in our ocean, there is no such pearl.
They then ordered the sea gods to take it by force.
The god transformed into a human and met with Daoyi.
He asked,

original: 聞卿得奇異之物寧可借視。
analyzed: 聞卿得奇異之物寧可借視。
translated: I heard you obtained extraordinary items. May I borrow a look?
Daoyi extended his hand to show the four pearls.

original: 海神便搖其手使珠墮水。
analyzed: 海神便搖其手使珠墮水。
translated: The sea god shook his hand, causing the pearls to fall into the water.
Daoyi thought to himself,
The king told me,
'This pearl is hard to keep.'
I was fortunate to obtain it,
but now it has been taken away by this child. It is not right.
He then said to the sea god,

original: 我自勤苦經涉險阻得此珠來。
analyzed: 我自勤苦經涉險阻得此珠來。
translated: I have toiled and traveled through dangers to obtain this pearl.
You have taken it from me. If you do not return it to me now,

original: 我當抒盡海水。🔽海神知之。
analyzed: 我當抒盡海水。 海神知之。
translated: I will drain the ocean waters.
The sea god knew this and asked,
Your resolve is extraordinary.

original: 海深三百三十六萬由延。
analyzed: 海深三百三十六萬由延。
translated: The ocean is 3,360,000 yojanas deep.
Its height is boundless.

original: 奈何竭之如日終不墮地。
analyzed: 奈何竭之如日終不墮地。
translated: How can it be exhausted? It is like the sun that will never fall to the ground.
It is like a great wind that cannot be grasped.
The sun can still fall.
The wind can still be grasped.

original: 大海水不可抒令竭也。🔽大意笑答之言。
analyzed: 大海水不可抒令竭也。 大意笑答之言。
translated: The water of the great ocean cannot be scooped out to dry it up.

original: 我自念前後受身生死壞敗。
analyzed: 我自念前後受身生死壞敗。
translated: Daoyi laughed and replied, I think of the bodies I have received in the past, the destruction of birth and death.
The bones I have accumulated surpass Mount Sumeru.
The blood I have shed surpasses the flow of the five rivers.
I still want to cut off the root of birth and death.
But this small ocean is not enough to not scoop out.
I made offerings to the buddhas in the past and vowed to say,

original: 令我志行勇於道決所尚無難。
analyzed: 令我志行勇於道決所尚無難。
translated: 'Let my will and practice be courageous in the Way, and what I aspire to will not be difficult.'
I will move Mount Sumeru and dry up the great ocean.
I will never retreat in intention.
He then single-mindedly used a vessel to scoop out the ocean water.

original: 精誠之意四天王來助大意。
analyzed: 精誠之意四天王來助大意。
translated: With his sincere intention, the Four Heavenly Kings came to assist Daoyi.
Two-thirds of the water had been scooped out.

original: 於是海中諸神皆大振怖。
analyzed: 於是海中諸神皆大振怖。
translated: Then all the spirits in the ocean were greatly frightened.
They discussed together, saying:
Not returning the pearl is not a small matter.
The water will dry up and the mud will emerge, destroying our palaces.

original: 海神於是便出眾寶以與大意。
analyzed: 海神於是便出眾寶以與大意。
translated: The sea god then took out various treasures and gave them to the Great Intention.
The Great Intention did not accept them.
He only wanted to get my pearl.
He will never let it go.

original: 海神知其意盛便出珠還之。
analyzed: 海神知其意盛便出珠還之。
translated: The sea god knew his intentions were strong and took out the pearl and returned it.
The Great Intention obtained the pearl and returned to his homeland.
He gave generously to all.

original: 自是以後境界無復飢寒窮乏之者。
analyzed: 自是以後境界無復飢寒窮乏之者。
translated: From then on, there were no longer those in the realm who were hungry, cold, or destitute.
The Buddha told the monks:
The Great Intention of the past
was none other than myself.
Ānanda addressed the Buddha, saying:

original: 以何功德致此四珠眾寶隨之。
analyzed: 以何功德致此四珠眾寶隨之。
translated: By what merit did he attain these four pearls and various treasures following him?
The Buddha said:
In the time of Vipaśyin Buddha,

original: 大意當以四寶為佛起塔。
analyzed: 大意當以四寶為佛起塔。
translated: the Great Intention should have used the four treasures to build a stūpa for the Buddha,
and made offerings to the Three Jewels while observing the precepts for seven days.
At that time, there were five hundred people.

original: 同時共起寺。🔽或懸繒燃燈者。
analyzed: 同時共起寺。 或懸繒燃燈者。
translated: At the same time, they built a temple together.🔽Some hung silk and lit lamps,
some burned incense and scattered flowers,
some made offerings to the bhikṣu sangha,
some recited sūtras and lectured on them.
Now they all encountered the Buddha and were all liberated.
Therefore, the Saṃghabhedavastu says:
At that time, the sea god had this thought:
Even if I were to bail out the seawater for a hundred years,
I would still not be able to reduce it by even a hair's breadth.

original: 感其專精即還其寶。🔽是時海神為婆羅門。
analyzed: 感其專精即還其寶。 是時海神為婆羅門。
translated: Moved by his single-minded effort, [the sea god] returned his treasure.
At that time, the sea god spoke a verse to the brāhmaṇa, saying:

original: 精勤方便力　　志意不休息
analyzed: 精勤方便力　　志意不休息
translated: With the power of diligent effort, one's resolve is not at rest.

original: 專精之所感　　雖失復還得
analyzed: 專精之所感　　雖失復還得
translated: Moved by single-minded effort, even if lost, one regains it.

original: 3 求戒部求戒部第三如雜譬喻經云。
analyzed: 3 求戒部求戒部第三如雜譬喻經云。
translated: The section on seeking precepts, part 3, is as stated in the Za piyu jing:
In the past, there was a person named Sabao.

original: 聞於外國更有異寶欲往治生。
analyzed: 聞於外國更有異寶欲往治生。
translated: He heard that there were more rare treasures in a foreign country and wanted to go there to do business.

original: 而二國中間有羅剎難不可得過。
analyzed: 而二國中間有羅剎難不可得過。
translated: But between the two countries, there was the danger of rākṣasas, and it was impossible to pass through.

original: 薩薄游行見市西門有一道人空床上坐云賣五戒。
analyzed: 薩薄游行見市西門有一道人空床上坐云賣五戒。
translated: The merchant traveled and saw a man sitting on an empty bed at the west gate of the market, saying he was selling the five precepts.
The merchant asked,
What are the five precepts?
He replied,
They are formless.
They are directly transmitted orally and upheld in the mind, leading to rebirth in the heavens in the future.
In this life, they can ward off the dangers of rākṣasas and ghosts.
The merchant wanted to buy them.
He asked how much they cost.
The man said, One thousand gold coins.
The merchant then received them.
The man said,
When you go to a foreign country and reach the border,
if a rākṣasa comes, you should say,
'I am a disciple of the five precepts of Śākyamuni.'
After a short while, the merchant reached the middle of the two countries.

original: 見有羅剎身長一丈三尺。
analyzed: 見有羅剎身長一丈三尺。
translated: He saw a rākṣasa, one zhang and three chi tall,
with yellow hair like reeds and eyes like red insects.
His entire body was covered in scales.
They opened their mouths alternately, like a fish flapping its gills.
They reached up to catch flying swallows and their feet sank into the ground up to their knees.
Hot blood flowed from their mouths.
Thousands of them rushed to grab him.
The merchant said:
I am a disciple of the five precepts of Shakyamuni.
The rakshasa heard this but still refused to let go.

original: 薩薄聊以兩捲扠之。🔽捲入鱗甲拔不得出。
analyzed: 薩薄聊以兩捲扠之。 捲入鱗甲拔不得出。
translated: The merchant tried to pry it off with his two fists.🔽His fists got stuck in the scales and he couldn't pull them out.

original: 又以脚蹋頭衝拔復不出。
analyzed: 又以脚蹋頭衝拔復不出。
translated: He tried to pull it out with his feet but still couldn't.
His whole body was stuck in the scales.
Only his back could move.
The rakshasa spoke in verse, saying:

original: 汝身及手足　　一切悉被羈
analyzed: 汝身及手足　　一切悉被羈
translated: Your body and limbs are all bound.

original: 但當去就死　　跳踉復何為
analyzed: 但當去就死　　跳踉復何為
translated: You should just go and die. What's the use of struggling?
The merchant's determination was still firm.
He spoke to the rakshasa in verse, saying:

original: 我身及手足　　一時雖被繫
analyzed: 我身及手足　　一時雖被繫
translated: Although my body and limbs are all bound at once,

original: 攝心如金石　　終不為汝斃
analyzed: 攝心如金石　　終不為汝斃
translated: I will keep my mind like gold and stone and never die for you.
The rakshasa then said to the merchant:

original: 吾是鬼中王　　為人多力膂
analyzed: 吾是鬼中王　　為人多力膂
translated: I am the king of ghosts, with great strength and courage.

original: 從來食汝輩　　不可得稱數
analyzed: 從來食汝輩　　不可得稱數
translated: Since ancient times, I have eaten countless people like you.

original: 但當去就死　　何為自寬語
analyzed: 但當去就死　　何為自寬語
translated: You should just go and die. Why are you trying to comfort yourself with words?
The merchant wanted to scold and be angry again.

original: 自念此身輪迴三界未曾乞人。
analyzed: 自念此身輪迴三界未曾乞人。
translated: He thought to himself, This body has been wandering in the three realms and has never begged from anyone.

original: 我今當以乞此羅剎作頓飽食。
analyzed: 我今當以乞此羅剎作頓飽食。
translated: I will now use this begging to make the rākṣasa a meal that will satisfy him.
He then spoke a verse, saying:

original: 我此腥臊身　　久欲相去離
analyzed: 我此腥臊身　　久欲相去離
translated: This foul and stinking body, I have long wanted to part with it.

original: 羅剎得我便　　悉持以布施
analyzed: 羅剎得我便　　悉持以布施
translated: The rākṣasa has obtained me, I will give it all to him in alms.

original: 志求摩訶乘　　果成一切智
analyzed: 志求摩訶乘　　果成一切智
translated: With the aspiration seeking the Mahāyāna, I will accomplish the wisdom of all things.
The rākṣasa was intelligent and understood the merchant's words.
He then felt ashamed and let the merchant go.
He knelt for a long time with palms joined, apologizing to him, saying:

original: 君是度人師　　三界之希有
analyzed: 君是度人師　　三界之希有
translated: You are the teacher who delivers people, a rare one in the three realms.

original: 志求摩訶乘　　成佛當不久
analyzed: 志求摩訶乘　　成佛當不久
translated: Aspiring to seek the Mahāyāna, you will soon accomplish Buddhahood.

original: 是故自歸命　　頭面禮稽首
analyzed: 是故自歸命　　頭面禮稽首
translated: Therefore, I take refuge in you, bowing my head and paying homage.

original: 羅剎悔過竟送薩薄至外國。
analyzed: 羅剎悔過竟送薩薄至外國。
translated: When the rākṣasa's repentance was finished, he sent the merchant to a foreign country.
He obtained many precious treasures.
He was also sent back home.
He greatly cultivated merit and virtue and finally accomplished the Way.
Therefore, it is known that the power of precepts is inconceivable.
Encouraging practitioners to uphold the precepts firmly.
Still, this person's resolve is courageous.

original: 4 求忍部求忍部第四如智度論云。
analyzed: 4 求忍部求忍部第四如智度論云。
translated: The chapter on seeking patience, as stated in the Treatise on the Perfection of Wisdom:
There was a powerful poisonous dragon.
Gazing at people with its eyes, the weak would die.
Blowing its breath at people, the strong would also die.
At that time, the dragon observed the precepts for one day.
Going forth, it entered a grove of trees.
Meditating for a long time, it became tired and fell asleep.
According to the dragon's sleeping method, its form resembled a snake.
It was multicolored with the seven treasures.
A hunter saw it and was surprised and delighted, saying:
With this rare and precious skin,
I will present it to the king as a ship.
Isn't that appropriate?

original: 便以杖案其頭刀剝其皮。
analyzed: 便以杖案其頭刀剝其皮。
translated: He then used a stick to support its head and a knife to peel off its skin.
The dragon thought to itself:
My power can topple a country.
This one small thing,
how can it trouble me?

original: 我今以持戒故不計此身。
analyzed: 我今以持戒故不計此身。
translated: I now do not care about this body because I uphold the precepts.
I should follow the Buddha's words.
He himself endured, closing his eyes and not looking.
He stopped breathing and did not pant.
He pitied this person.

original: 為持戒故一心受剝不生悔意。
analyzed: 為持戒故一心受剝不生悔意。
translated: For the sake of upholding the precepts, he single-mindedly accepted the flaying without giving rise to regret.
Having lost his skin and raw flesh on the ground,
in the great heat of the day he rolled in the dirt.

original: 欲趣大水見諸小蟲來食其身。
analyzed: 欲趣大水見諸小蟲來食其身。
translated: Wishing to go to the great waters, he saw small insects coming to eat his body.
For the sake of upholding the precepts, he did not dare move again.
He thought to himself:
Now I offer this body of mine to the insects.
For the sake of the Buddha's Way.
Now I offer my flesh to satisfy their bodies.
Later I will offer the Dharma to benefit their minds.

original: 身乾命終即生忉利天上。
analyzed: 身乾命終即生忉利天上。
translated: His body dried up, and when his life ended he was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Even animals are able to firmly uphold the precepts.
They do not violate them even unto death.
How much more so for humans.
How could they deliberately violate them?
Moreover, the Five Part Vinaya says:

original: 佛言。🔽乃往過去有一黑蛇。
analyzed: 佛言。 乃往過去有一黑蛇。
translated: The Buddha said:🔽In the past there was a black snake.
It bit a calf and returned to its hole.
There was a spell-caster who used a spell on a ewe.
He cast a spell to make it come out of the hole.
He was unable to make it come out.

original: 呪師便於犢子前燃火呪之。
analyzed: 呪師便於犢子前燃火呪之。
translated: The spell-caster then lit a fire in front of the calf and cast a spell on it.
It transformed into a fire bee.
It entered the snake's hole and burned the snake.
The snake could not bear the pain.
It then came out of the hole.
The ewe used its horns to pick it up and put it in front of the spell-caster.
The spell-caster said:

original: 汝還舐毒不爾投此火中。
analyzed: 汝還舐毒不爾投此火中。
translated: If you do not lick the poison back, I will throw you into this fire.
The black snake then spoke a verse, saying:

original: 我既吐此毒　　終不還收之
analyzed: 我既吐此毒　　終不還收之
translated: Since I have vomited this poison, I will never take it back.

original: 若有死事至　　畢命不復迴
analyzed: 若有死事至　　畢命不復迴
translated: If there is a matter of death, I will give up my life and not return.

original: 於是遂不收毒自投火中。
analyzed: 於是遂不收毒自投火中。
translated: Thus, it did not take back the poison and threw itself into the fire.
The Buddha said:
At that time, the black snake
is now Śāriputra.

original: 昔受如此死苦猶不收毒。
analyzed: 昔受如此死苦猶不收毒。
translated: In the past, he suffered such a painful death and still did not take back the poison.
How much less would he now take the discarded medicine?

original: 5 求進部求進部第五如雜寶藏經云。
analyzed: 5 求進部求進部第五如雜寶藏經云。
translated: The chapter on seeking progress, number five, is as stated in the Saṃyukta-ratna-piṭaka-sūtra:
The Buddha said:
In the past,

original: 亦復曾於迦尸國毘提醯國二國中間有大曠野。
analyzed: 亦復曾於迦尸國毘提醯國二國中間有大曠野。
translated: in the middle of the two countries of Kāśi and Videha, there was a great wilderness.
There was an evil ghost named Śatānīka.
He blocked the road.
No people could pass through.
There was a caravan leader.
His name was Siṃha.
He was leading five hundred merchants to pass through this road.
The people were terrified and afraid they could not pass through.
The caravan leader said,
Be careful not to be afraid.
Just follow behind me.
Then he went ahead to where the ghost was.
And said to the ghost,
Have you not heard my name?
The ghost replied,
I have heard your name, so I came to fight you.
The caravan leader asked,
What can you do?
He then took up his bow and arrows and shot the ghost.
Five hundred arrows all disappeared into the ghost's belly.
The bow, sword, and weapons also entered the ghost's belly.
He then punched with his fist, and the fist also went in.

original: 以右手托右手亦著。🔽以右脚蹋右脚亦著。
analyzed: 以右手托右手亦著。 以右脚蹋右脚亦著。
translated: He used his right hand to support his right hand, which also stuck.
He used his right foot to step on his right foot, which also stuck.🔽He used his left foot to step on his left foot, which also stuck.
He also used his head to hit his head, which also stuck.
The ghost spoke a verse, saying:

original: 汝以手脚及與頭　　一切諸物悉以著
analyzed: 汝以手脚及與頭　　一切諸物悉以著
translated: You have used your hands, feet, and head - all things have stuck.

original: 餘有何物而不著商主說偈而答言。
analyzed: 餘有何物而不著商主說偈而答言。
translated: What other things are there that do not stick? The caravan leader spoke a verse in reply, saying:

original: 我今手足及與頭　　一切財錢及刀仗
analyzed: 我今手足及與頭　　一切財錢及刀仗
translated: My hands, feet, and head - all wealth, money, and weapons,

original: 此諸雜物雖入沒　　唯有精進不著汝🔽精進若當不休息　　與汝鬪諍終不廢
analyzed: 此諸雜物雖入沒　　唯有精進不著汝 精進若當不休息　　與汝鬪諍終不廢
translated: Although these various things have sunk, only my diligence does not stick to you.🔽If my diligence does not rest, I will fight with you to the end.

original: 我今精進不休息　　終不於汝生怖畏
analyzed: 我今精進不休息　　終不於汝生怖畏
translated: My diligence will not rest, and I will never be afraid of you.
At that time, the ghost replied:
For your sake,
I will release all five hundred merchants.

original: 6 求定部求定部第六如新婆沙論云。
analyzed: 6 求定部求定部第六如新婆沙論云。
translated: As for seeking concentration, the Xinposha lun says:

You definitely will not be able to realize supreme enlightenment.

What you say now is like enticing a child.
The sun, moon, and stars can be made to fall,
and the mountains, forests, and earth can be made to ascend into the sky,

analyzed: 欲令我今不取大覺起此座者。

holding weapons of boundless types,
covering an area of thirty-six yojanas.

analyzed: 俱時奔趣菩提樹下惱亂菩薩。
translated: All at once they rushed to the foot of the bodhi tree to disturb the Bodhisattva.
None of them could obtain it.

original: 菩薩身心不動逾須彌山也。
analyzed: 菩薩身心不動逾須彌山也。
translated: The bodhisattva's body and mind were unmoving, surpassing Mount Sumeru.

The Buddha's teachings are vast and boundless in their salvation.
Those who sincerely seek the Way will all attain its fruits.
Even those who joke will not waste their blessings.
As in the past,
there was an old bhikṣu.
He was already old and his spirit was dull.

original: 見諸年少比丘種種說法。
analyzed: 見諸年少比丘種種說法。
translated: He saw the various teachings expounded by the young bhikṣus.
Hearing about the four fruits, his mind was filled with admiration.
He said to the young bhikṣus:
You are all wise and intelligent.
I wish to obtain the four fruits from you.
The young bhikṣus scoffed and said:
We have the four fruits.
We need good food before we can give them to you.
When the old bhikṣu heard these words,
he was delighted and immediately prepared various delicacies.
He invited the young bhikṣus to seek the four fruits.
After the young bhikṣus had eaten his food,

original: 更相指麾弄老比丘語言。
analyzed: 更相指麾弄老比丘語言。
translated: They pointed at each other and teased the old monk, saying:
Venerable sir.
Sit in the corner of this house.
We will give you the fruit.
At that time, the old monk, having heard this, was delighted.
He sat as instructed.

original: 諸少比丘即以皮毱打其頭上。
analyzed: 諸少比丘即以皮毱打其頭上。
translated: The young monks then hit his head with a leather ball,
and said to him:
This is the fruit of stream-entry.
The old monk, having heard this, focused his mind without distraction.
He immediately attained the first fruit.
The young monks continued to tease him, saying:
Although we have given you the fruit of stream-entry,
you still have seven more births and deaths.
Move to another corner.
Next, we will give you the fruit of once-returning.

original: 時老比丘獲初果故心轉增進。
analyzed: 時老比丘獲初果故心轉增進。
translated: At that time, the old monk, having attained the first fruit, his mind became even more advanced.
He then moved his seat again.
The young monks again hit his head with a ball,
and said to him:
We give you the second fruit.
At that time, the old monk focused his mind even more intently.
He then realized the second fruit.
The younger monks teased him again, saying,
You have now attained the fruit of once-returning,
but you still have the difficulty of coming and going in birth and death.
You should move your seat again,
and I will give you the fruit of non-returning.
At that time, the old monk moved his seat as instructed.
The younger monks again hit him with the ball,
and said to him,
I will now give you the third fruit.
When the old monk heard this, he was overjoyed,
and his utmost sincerity doubled.
He immediately attained the fruit of non-returning.

original: 然故於色無色界受有漏身。
analyzed: 然故於色無色界受有漏身。
translated: However, he still received a body with outflows in the form and formless realms,
impermanent and changing, moment by moment suffering.

original: 汝更移坐次當與爾阿羅漢果。
analyzed: 汝更移坐次當與爾阿羅漢果。
translated: You should move your seat again, and I will next give you the fruit of arhatship.
At that time, the old monk moved his seat as instructed.

original: 諸少比丘復以皮毱撩打其頭。
analyzed: 諸少比丘復以皮毱撩打其頭。
translated: The younger monks again hit his head with the ball,
and said to him,
I will now give you the fourth fruit.

original: 時老比丘一心思惟即證阿羅漢果。
analyzed: 時老比丘一心思惟即證阿羅漢果。
translated: At that time, the old monk single-mindedly contemplated and immediately realized the fruit of arhatship.
Having attained the four fruits, he was overjoyed.
He prepared various delicacies and fragrant flowers.
He invited the young monk to repay his kindness and virtue.

original: 與少比丘共論道品無漏功德。
analyzed: 與少比丘共論道品無漏功德。
translated: He discussed the undefiled merits of the path with the young monk.
The young monks' words were stuck.
At that time, the old monk said to them,
I have already attained the fruit of arhatship.
The young monks heard these words.
They all repented of the sin of their previous jesting.
Therefore, practitioners should always think of goodness.
Even jesting can still bring real rewards.
How much more so if done with utmost sincerity!
Moreover, the Za bao zang jing says:

original: 若人求道要在精誠相感。
analyzed: 若人求道要在精誠相感。
translated: If a person seeks the Way, it is important to be sincere and moved by the Way.
One can attain the fruit of the Way.
As in the past, there was a woman.
She was intelligent and wise.
She deeply believed in the Three Jewels.
She always invited two bhikṣus in the order of the sangha.
and made offerings in her house.
At that time, there was an old monk.
He was next to go to her house.
Being old and dull-witted, he had no knowledge or understanding.
At that time, after the woman had finished her meal,
she requested the old monk to speak the Dharma for her.
She alone spread out a seat and closed her eyes in silent stillness.

original: 時老比丘自知愚闇不知說法。
analyzed: 時老比丘自知愚闇不知說法。
translated: At that time, the old monk, knowing himself to be foolish and ignorant and not knowing how to speak the Dharma,
went to sleep and ran back to the temple.

original: 然此女人至心思惟有為之法無常苦空不得自在。
analyzed: 然此女人至心思惟有為之法無常苦空不得自在。
translated: However, this woman deeply contemplated impermanent, suffering, and empty conditioned phenomena, and that one cannot attain mastery over them.
With a sincere mind, she deeply observed and attained the first fruit [of the path].
Having attained the fruit,
she sought the old monk to repay his kindness.

original: 此老比丘審己無知棄他走避。
analyzed: 此老比丘審己無知棄他走避。
translated: This old monk, knowing himself to be ignorant and having avoided him,
was even more ashamed and again hid himself.
But this woman earnestly sought him without giving up.
Only then did he appear himself.

original: 女人於時具論上來蒙得道果。
analyzed: 女人於時具論上來蒙得道果。
translated: At that time, the woman fully discussed how she had attained the fruit of the path.
Therefore, she brought offerings to repay his great kindness.
At that time, the old bhikṣu, out of shame and remorse,
deeply reproached himself and immediately attained the first fruit [of the śramaṇa].
Therefore, practitioners should be sincere.
If one is sincere, one will surely attain what one seeks.

original: 8 濟難部濟難部第八如僧伽羅剎經云。
analyzed: 8 濟難部濟難部第八如僧伽羅剎經云。
translated: The chapter on saving from difficulties, the eighth, is as stated in the Saṃgharakṣa Sūtra:
In the past, the Bodhisattva
appeared as a parrot always staying in a tree.
The wind blew the tree, rubbing against each other,
causing fire to appear.
The fire gradually grew and eventually burned a mountain.
The parrot thought:
Just like a flying bird whose body rests in a tree,
one should therefore be grateful and give rise to a mind of repaying kindness.

original: 何況於我長夜處之而不滅火。
analyzed: 何況於我長夜處之而不滅火。
translated: How much more so for me, who has stayed here for a long time, not extinguishing the fire.
He then went to the ocean,
using his two wings to take water from the great ocean,
reaching the fire above and sprinkling it on the fire.
Sometimes he sprinkled with his mouth, running around east and west.
At that time, there was a good spirit,
moved by his hard work,
soon extinguishing the fire.
Moreover, the Mahāprajñāpāramitā Śāstra says:
In the past, a forest fire burned a forest.
In the forest, there was a pheasant.
It diligently flew back and forth, entering the water.
Using the water to sprinkle the forest.
Going back and forth, exhausted, but not considering it difficult.
At that time, the Heavenly Emperor came and asked,
What are you doing?
It replied,
I am saving this forest.
Out of compassion for sentient beings.
This forest has provided shade and shelter for a long time.
It is cool and pleasant.
All my kind and relatives
All depend on it.
I have the strength of my body.
How can I not save it?
The Heavenly Emperor asked,
How long will you work diligently?
The pheasant said,
Until death.
The Heavenly Emperor said,
Who will bear witness for you?
It then made a vow,
If my sincere heart is true and my faith is not false,
I wish the fire will extinguish itself.
At that time, the Heaven of Pure Abode knew the pheasant's great vow,
And immediately extinguished the fire.

original: 始終常茂不為火燒故經云人有善願天必從之斯言驗矣。
analyzed: 始終常茂不為火燒故經云人有善願天必從之斯言驗矣。

Walking at night, he saw a sleeping stone.
Mistaking it for a crouching tiger,
he drew his bow and shot at it.
The golden arrowhead sank into the stone.
Looking down, he realized it was a stone.

original: 復射之矢摧無跡漢世復有李廣。
analyzed: 復射之矢摧無跡漢世復有李廣。

He served as the governor of Youbeiping.
Shooting a tiger, he obtained a stone, just like that.
Liu Xiang said:
The utmost sincerity.
And gold and stone open up for it.

analyzed: 況人乎。 夫倡而不和。
translated: How much more so for humans!🔽If one leads but does not harmonize,
moves but does not follow,
there must be something incomplete in the middle.
Those who rectify the world without descending from their seat
seek it in themselves.

original: 楚干將莫耶藏劍楚干將莫耶。
analyzed: 楚干將莫耶藏劍楚干將莫耶。
translated: Chu Ganjiang and Moye hid their swords Chu Ganjiang and Moye.
They made swords for the King of Chu.
After three years, they were completed.
The king was angry and wanted to kill them.
The swords had male and female aspects.
His wife was pregnant and about to give birth.
Her husband said to his wife:
I made a sword for the king for three years before it was completed.
The king was angry and would surely kill me.
If you give birth to a son,
Tell him this:
Go out the door and look to the south,
On the rock there is a pine tree, and the sword is behind it.

original: 於是即將雌劍往見楚王。
analyzed: 於是即將雌劍往見楚王。
translated: Then take the female sword and show it to the king of Chu.
The king of Chu was greatly enraged and ordered it to be examined.
The sword had two parts, male and female.
The female came, but the male did not.
The king was furious and had it destroyed.
Mo Ye's son was named Chi.
Later, when he grew up, he asked his mother,
Where is my father?
His mother said,
Your father made a sword for the king of Chu.
It took three years to complete.
The king was angry and killed him.
When he left, he entrusted me to tell you,
'Go out the door and look to the south,
On the rock there is a pine tree, and the sword is behind it.'

original: 於是子出戶望南不見有山。
analyzed: 於是子出戶望南不見有山。
translated: Then the son went out the door and looked, but he did not see any mountains.

original: 但覩堂前松柱下石砥之上。
analyzed: 但覩堂前松柱下石砥之上。
translated: He only saw a pine pillar in front of the hall, and on top of the whetstone,
Then he used an axe to break open his back and obtained the sword.
Day and night he thought of wanting to avenge King Chu.

original: 楚王夢見一兒眉間廣尺。
analyzed: 楚王夢見一兒眉間廣尺。
translated: King Chu dreamed of a child with eyebrows as wide as a foot.
Wanting to take revenge.
The king immediately offered a thousand gold coins for him.
The child, hearing of this, ran away and entered the mountains, singing as he went.
There were guests who encountered him.

original: 謂子年少何哭之甚悲耶。
analyzed: 謂子年少何哭之甚悲耶。
translated: They said, You are young, why are you crying so sadly?
He said, I am the son of Ganjiang and Mo Ye.
King Chu killed my father.
I want to avenge him.
The guests said,
We heard that the king is offering a thousand gold coins for your head.

original: 將子頭與劍來為子報之。
analyzed: 將子頭與劍來為子報之。
translated: Bring the child's head and sword to us and we will avenge you.
The child said,
How fortunate!

original: 即自刎兩手捧頭及劍奉之。
analyzed: 即自刎兩手捧頭及劍奉之。
translated: He immediately cut off his own head, held it in both hands along with the sword, and offered it to them.
He stood there without falling over.
The guests said,
We will not let you down.
Then the corpse fell over.
The guests took the head and went to see King Chu.
King Chu was greatly delighted.
The guests said,
This is the head of a warrior.
It should be cooked in boiling water.
The king did as he said.
Boiled the head for three days and three nights, it still did not rot.
The head emerged from the boiling water, and the eyes rolled. Mo Da was furious.
The guest said,
This child's head will not rot.
I wish the king would personally inspect it.

analyzed: 是必爛也。 王即臨之。
translated: It will certainly rot.🔽The king then inspected it.
The guest raised his sword and struck the king.
The king's head fell into the boiling water.
The guest also raised his sword and struck his own head.
The head also fell into the boiling water.
All three rotted together, indistinguishable.
The boiling water and flesh were divided and buried.

original: 故通名三王墓今在汝南北宜春縣界。
analyzed: 故通名三王墓今在汝南北宜春縣界。
translated: Therefore, they are collectively called the Tomb of the Three Kings. It is now in the border area of Yichun County, north of Ru.

original: 宋韓憑妻康王奪宋時大夫韓馮娶妻而美。
analyzed: 宋韓憑妻康王奪宋時大夫韓馮娶妻而美。
translated: During the time when King Kang of the state of Kang took away the wife of Han Feng, a great officer of the state of Song, Han Feng married a beautiful wife.
King Kang took her away.
Feng resented the king.
He was imprisoned and discussed building a city.
Moreover, his wife secretly sent a letter to Feng.
The words were distorted, saying,
It has rained heavily and incessantly.
The river is very deep. The sun rises in my heart.

original: 既而王得其書以示左右。
analyzed: 既而王得其書以示左右。
translated: Then the king obtained the letter and showed it to his attendants.

original: 左右莫解其意。🔽臣賀對曰。
analyzed: 左右莫解其意。 臣賀對曰。
translated: Those on the left and right did not understand his meaning.
Minister He replied, It is raining heavily.
The words 'autumn morning thoughts' are used.
The river is very deep,
so one cannot come and go.
The sun rises in the heart,
there must be a will to die.
Soon after, Feng committed suicide.
His wife then secretly rotted his clothes.
The king went up to the platform with her.
His wife then threw herself off the platform.
Those on the left and right grabbed her.

original: 衣不中手而死。🔽遺書於帶曰。
analyzed: 衣不中手而死。 遺書於帶曰。
translated: Her clothes were not caught by their hands and she died.
A note on her belt said, The king benefits from her life.
I benefit from her death.
I wish to be buried together with Feng's corpse and bones.
The king was angry and did not listen.
He ordered the tombs in the village to face each other.
He said,
You two, husband and wife, loved each other so much.

original: 若能使塚合則吾弗禁也。🔽宿昔之間便有交梓木。
analyzed: 若能使塚合則吾弗禁也。 宿昔之間便有交梓木。
translated: If you can make the tombs join, I will not stop you.🔽In the middle of the night, there was a connection between the two trees.

original: 於二塚之端旬日而大盈抱。
analyzed: 於二塚之端旬日而大盈抱。
translated: In a few days, it grew to the size of a full embrace.
It bent over to join together.

original: 根交於下枝錯於上。🔽又有鴛鴦雌雄各一。
analyzed: 根交於下枝錯於上。 又有鴛鴦雌雄各一。
